New rules in the free tier mean that only 3 devices can connect to the account. What ever about restricting the starage space, restricting the number of devices to 3 makes this service useless to me. I have 3 os's on my laptop apart from my desktop pc, phones and tablets. Another dumb decision by an exec that is likely to lead to the downfall of a good service. The software has worked well up to now and I chose dropbox because they had a native client for linux as well as other operating systems. Unfortunately now I have to switch to another cloud provider that is less restrictive.
Best of the best for linux developers
Nice Drop Box Client for linux and I used it in my ubuntu. Work well and neat

Had to download to the deb package from the Dropbox official site instead.
Dropbox works well with Ubuntu and syncs without any problem. It's a pleasure to use.
since the upgrade on Dropbox, it wont install on my AMD Quad core machine, bags of memory, bags of disk space yet it tell me my machine is not capable, was working fine before the upgrade
After putting a limit to how many devices you can connect, I'm done with dropbox.
A life saver for me that works fantastic. Totally recommend over Google Drive that doesn't support linux

Perfect. So glad this works so well now.

description: A very useful service and application - Ubuntu 21.04.
Either not installing or not launching the deamon installer
Current version does not install !

The developer of this nice app has no control over the features of Dropbox, which is a commercial project. Ie. how many devices you can sync etc. Ther are various levels of Dropbox with more or less features. 
Moaning about the limitations of Dropbox is not helpful here. This app merely enables one to access Dropbox on Linux distros. 
You have to subscribe and get a Dropbox account in the first place.
Dropbox itself offers desktop apps for various OS Mac, PC, Linux, but their Linux version does not run on Kubuntu. Their desktop app does run on Ubuntu.
This app enables Dropbox to run on Kubuntu and other Linux distros. I've only tried it on Ubuntu and Kubuntu.
summary: Please comment on the app, not the features of Dropbox

description: I'm a newbee in the linux world. I downloaded dropbox on my first computer and there were no issues. Didn't have to jump through any nautilus-terminal issues. description: i use and good

Sometimes my laptop is being booted very slow. After login I see a popup, here is said that Dropbox deamon installation is needed. The system is very slow every time, all cores are almost on 100%!
Temporary solution:
- Remove this app from here (Software app)
- Shut down laptop (reboot didn't helped in my case). After this the issue should be gone
- Then install app again and it works well

This is the 3rd time I bumped with the issue, please try to fix this if you can

Thank you!
The app works well, i've been using Dropbox as my main cloud for years. File sync works perfectly.

When we first started using it, in the dark ages, it was great. Now it is slow to sync and unreliable when it does. In todays world files are getting larger DB seem not to be able to handle zip files, encryped files, or very large graphics files without corrupting them. SAD

description: This system worked well for a while, but the more recent iterations of the app no longer work. There are many errors in the program, making it unusable. The documentation is virtually non-existent, and what 3rd party information I could find is either inaccurate or was never proofread for accuracy. I followed all the steps listed, but it just doesn't work.
It would be really nice to have a native app on linux but this software does not seem to work after being launched.
Is this up, Nautilus, up to date? Could it use some manual intervention or creativity? Basically, I am asking if it is possible to make this better? Are there any takers who want to give this a try?

completely pointless as it won't launch, so to that extent it is a waste of my disc space. This is a pity because a native app would be useful, as it is i will continue to sign in via the web interface. Sadly have had to uninstall, but will review if this if an updated and working version ever appears that works in Ununtu 22.04

Some peopel say: "doesn't launch at all". That happened to mee too. But I forgot this instruction (from dropbax.com/install) (64-bits cited here):

cd ~ && wget -O - "https://www.dropbox.com/download?plat=lnx.x86_64" | tar xzf -
# Next, start the deamon from .dropbox-dist:
~/.dropbox-dist/dropboxd

After this it worked perfectly
Worked flawlesly for me, but will not use an encrypted partition
summary: Worked perfectly... if you don't use encryption
